segments.text: I had come to New York, and when I came to New York on NMU business, I usually stayed in the apartment in the NMU building.
And Perry came in one night and said, Hoyt, I've just worked out the situation on the officer's slate.
I want to see what you think of it.
So he started that.
Mel Beresik, to replace Joe.
Then went on down the officers, and I said, well, let's go back to your number one.
Why did you select Mel Barisik as the number one?
He said, well, because he always does what he's told to do.
I said, well, that's not a very good reason as long as you're telling him what to do, because you're usually telling him the wrong thing to do.
So Perry said, what do you mean by that?
I said, well, I mean such things as you telling them to go down and shake down the steamship company for $5,000 for this and $5,000 for that, so it will go in your pocket.
He said, I don't think that's a good reason for selecting a man to be president of the union.
So.
I said, I don't think he ought to be president.
I think Shannon Wall ought to be president.
Oh, he's a bunch of bullshit.
I said, he's only a bunch of bullshit because you can't drive him around all the time and tell him what to do.
That's not enough reason.
This was some time before the thing finally came to head, maybe four or five months.
So he kept fussing around with this.
And he finally said, well, I finally decided that you're right.
It ought to be Shannon Wall.
And about that time, he got fired.
Not over that issue, but other issues.
But this is the kind of a guy he was.
All he wanted to do was control things.
He found out that he could control Joe not by,
trying to pay him off with anything, but by just using his ego.
But Joe again had decided to go after Mel Barisi.
And I said, Joe, I don't want to influence you on this.
I want you to make your own decision, which you always do.
For God's sake, go home and think about this.
Remember that Mel Berezik is going to replace Joe Kern.
He's not only got to carry on what Joe Kern has carried on in the past, but he's got to build on that in the future.
And you go home and think about this and think in terms of, is he the man that you really think
can carry this union on to the heights to which you have brought it.
That's all I had to say to him.
The next day, he called Shannon Wall and said, I want you to come to Florida with me.
And that's when he decided to put Shannon Wall in as president.
And subsequently retire himself.
And then he retired.
But you know, it's a funny thing.
Joe wouldn't retire until after I retired.
And at this time, Joe and I were on very bad personal terms over our job.
Over Perry?
Perry and his son.
Joe's son?
Yeah.
But even in those bad times, you feel that Joe Kern considered you as a very trusted counsel.
Yes, I do.
I still think he trusted my word because I had proved right too many times to him on the Perry thing was the last thing.
He couldn't help but recognize what I had been telling him to be the truth for so long.
See, I had delivered to him in writing names and dates and amounts on Perry of shaking down steamship corners, which he wouldn't believe.
Then he found out they were true.
He found out from one of the companies, too.
Said, sure, we paid Perry off.
We paid him over a half million dollars to get rid of our passenger ships.
Well, in your opinion, what was the result of the loss of the passenger ship contracts to the NMU?
Loss of half of their membership.
And you feel that Perry was at least indirectly, if not directly, responsible for that?
I'm sure the steamship companies could prove that he was responsible.
I can't.
And now that's something you don't want to put in your write-up.
I'm not asking for lawsuits, which I can't prove.
Absolutely.
Just briefly, going back to the 1945, 47, and 49 conventions, where the communists, particularly under Stack and under Myers, and later Lawrenson, decided to take Curran on and attempt to remove him.
Who was directing Joe Curran?
Nobody.
Helping him fight against him?
I was certainly meeting with him.
I'm trying to remember who was attorneys then.
If it was Cooper, Cooper was trying to help him.
I don't know whether Cooper was there then or not.
What about William L. Standard?
I think Standard was gone by that time.
I'm just not sure.
Standard would not have been helping him.
So any tactics that were used to help maneuver?
They were Joe's.
They were Joe's.
Nobody else's but Joe's.
It was literally the personal, his personal weight, his personal relations with the seamen.
Because the commies had that convention well organized and
Some of the commies themselves voted against Stack because they could not perceive the union without a Joe Curran as president.
In the 1947 convention, where Joe is much better organized,
Where was this convention?
Boston?
I'm not sure where that one was located.

One of the persons I interviewed mentioned that one of the techniques that Joe used in order to keep the floor open to comments from people who were more favorable toward him was to outmaneuver Stack and his followers who had, as you mentioned, had organized very well for the 45 convention.
Do you know of any techniques that Joe Kern used?
Well, he just knew the people, and he would call upon the people he knew who weren't commies, that's all.
A very simple chairmanship work.
Did you know, or were you cognizant of a technique he used where he issued procuring people a red card and had them place it on his book when they raised their hand to be recognized?
Seems to me that I remember that being done, but I'm not sure of it.
This may or may not be true.
I just don't remember.
It strikes a note, but not enough to bring anything to mind.
How influential was his first wife, Red, on him?
In terms of union activities, I would say almost nothing.
This was a personal relationship.
It didn't enter into the unionism.
She stayed very much out of it.
But in terms of, they were very close.
And anything that she would do that... She could tear him to pieces if she wanted to.
She never wanted to do that.
But she did.
She got cancer.
And she knew she had cancer long before June of it.
And on two or three occasions, she just got up and left.
because she couldn't face telling him.
And he didn't know where she was, and the son didn't know where she was or anything.
She did this twice, and this just practically wrecked Joe.
But this was just a personal relationship, and she was thinking more of him than she was of herself.
And she did the wrong thing, of course, to do it the way she did, because it didn't save him any pain.
really made more pain for him.
Would have been better if she'd have gone ahead and told him sooner.
Do you have any interesting anecdotes in your career as a lobbyist for the CIO Maritime Community, or in your relationship with Joe Kieran, or other members of the NMU that might be of interest?
or insights into his personality, his character, or his makeup?
Well, I would say that Joel Kearns basically was very steadfast.
If you were a friend of his, you were a friend of his.
And if he believed in you, he believed in you wholeheartedly.
Perry is a good example of this.
He just trusted Perry almost completely right up until the end.
And he would do anything for Perry.
But he was like that with anyone that he trusted.
I think he basically trusted most people until they crossed him.
From your own personal opinion, what would you consider to be your greatest accomplishment for maritime labor?
Nothing.
Nothing?
Literally nothing.
I spent from 1941 to 1972 down here working for the merchant marine.
It was in worse shape when I left than it was when I started.
So I don't consider that any accomplishment whatsoever.
Some people say that I helped keep it from being completely wiped out.
Well, I don't consider that any accomplishment either.
Maybe it would have been better completely wiped out than to screw along as it is now.
He's the only president that ever hung up a phone on me.
I called him one day.
He was pushing an omnibus tax bill.

And I called him up and I said, Mr. President, with all of your experience in the Senate and as president and as vice president, you undoubtedly know that historically no omnibus tax bill has ever gotten passed that was not worse than when it started out.
I said, I want to suggest to you that if there is something you want
done in taxes that you take it up one at a time and do it.
He says, Hoyt, I've decided to push the omnibus tax bill, which I asked to get him pressed.
I said, but Mr. President, you know.
And he hung up on me.
So I can say that he's the only president that's ever hung up on me.
Literally, we took every program that we could.

One of the things that the union was interested in was making the merchant seaman a part of the community, wherever he came from, and making him a respectable part of that community, even though he was away from home.
So we did everything or anything that we could do that we thought would implement that idea.
Did you have any particular ideas that you presented?
I had a lot of ideas, but I don't remember them.
Matter of fact, if I don't put them down on paper, I don't remember them five minutes, just like yesterday.
I called the United Seaman Service.
I had developed a whole group of things that I wanted in a
manual for the board members of the United Seaman Service.
And we brought it up at a national of my nominating committee, where we discussed them, and adopted them, and recommended them to the next board meeting, and got them adopted.
And I didn't have a copy of them, so I called the office in New York for a copy of them, because the office yet had not implemented the resolution.
I wanted to know why they hadn't, and I said,
Give me the list of them so I'm going to put together a package of my own, and I'll give it to you.
Then you have got to do the thing for the rest of the board members.
But that's true on almost anything I work on.
First of all, I do have a bad memory.
Second of all, I do not try to remember things which I know are going to be recorded.
Make no attempt to.
But I've worked out thousands of programs for the unions and the United Seaman's Service, Four Freedoms, and what have you.
I don't know what they are.
I could go look at them, read through and find them, and say, yes, I had something to do with that, put that together.
